p: However, while the vaccine-specific T cell responses did not differ quantitatively between CMV − and CMV + individuals, there was a marked qualitative difference. In CMV + individuals, both the Ebola GP–specific CD4 + and CD8 + T cells contained significantly higher proportions of CD57 +KLRG1 + cells than in CMV − participants. This was particularly pronounced in the CD8 + subsets, in which 19% were CD57 +KLRG1 + in CMV + participants compared with 5% in CMV − participants ( Fig. 4 D; P = 0.029 for CD4 + and P = 0.0003 for CD8 + T cells). Additionally, the proportions of CD57 +KLRG1 + cells within both the Ebola GP–specific CD4 + and CD8 + T cells were negatively associated with IFN-γ and IL2 responses to GP ( Fig. 4, E–H). Although CMV-associated changes in the global T cell repertoire have previously been observed, this is the first study to demonstrate phenotypic differences in antigen-responsive T cells after vaccination in CMV + individuals.
